div.p: This sub-element within POLITICS and CULTURALFORMATION (in the BIOGRAPHY section of entries) tracks the beliefs, affiliations, connections, activities, and associations which designate a person's political life. Use it for mature commitment or for early exposure (like the devoted Communist activism of Jackie Kay’s adoptive parents). Encloses the names of political parties, but also of broader movements: imperialist or pacifist or vegetarian. These affiliations can be both formal connections to a party or organization and informal political positions held by the writer. We hope to point our readers towards women writers associated with different political positions and help researchers make links between political beliefs and writing. For this reason, we are defining POLITICALAFFILIATIONs broadly and include things like against capital punishment or strong supporter of the Empire (imperialist), or campaigner against vivisection or for animal rights, in addition to more straightforward affiliations such as marxist or conservative.

POLITICALAFFILIATION has optional attributes of ACTIVISM, INVOLVEMENT, MEMBERSHIP (for three alternative levels of commitment: choose only one for a single element), and WOMAN-GENDERISSUE, to specify the level and type of affiliation described. Other optional attributes are REG (which allows you to use a standard term if you have been unable to do in your prose: strong supporter of the Empire" REG=”imperialist), CURRENTALTERNATIVETERM (for use when a historical term has been replaced with a new one: Whig Reg=Liberal), and Id (an attribute which is NOT to be used). Try to include at least one POLITICALAFFILIATION sub-element in all POLITICS elements.

Working for suffrage was a common political activity and so can be tagged as POLITICALAFFILIATION. If the term or some equivalent is not used, include an empty PoliticalAffiliation element and capture this information in the Reg attribute:
div.codeblock: She worked tirelessly for the cause of <POLITICALAFFILIATION REG=”suffragist”>votes for woman</POLITICALAFFILIATION>. <POLITICALAFFILIATION woman-genderIssue=genderYes>Enlightenment feminism</POLITICALAFFILIATION> <POLITICALAFFILIATION INVOLVEMENT="InvolvementYes">Socialist</POLITICALAFFILIATION> <POLITICALAFFILIATION REG=”pro-animal rights”>working for animal rights</POLITICALAFFILIATION

div.p: Tag all organized political parties and organizations with ORGNAME (for example, Labour Party, PEN International). Tagging an OrgName within Politics does not denote that the person supported this organization. She may have protested vehemently against the Tory Party but Tory Party should be given an ORGNAME element. If she was a full supporter of the Tory Party, then as well as using ORGNAME, use a PoliticalAffiliation tag.
Try to use one the attributes to specify the level of affiliation, but leave blank if unknown or if they do not apply.

To the best of your ability, try to construct a sentence which allows you to put a POLITICALAFFILIATION tag around a word or short phrase. Instead of She protested against the Darlington nuclear facility, use Her anti-nuclear position informed protest against the Darlington nuclear facility, placing the tag around anti-nuclear rather than around protested against the Darlington nuclear facility.
Question: When all you know about a woman writer is that she wrote radical feminist and working-class plays, how do you tag her POLITICALAFFILIATION?

Answer: Discussion of political involvement will often involve making judgement calls. While critical discussion of the politics of her plays will be included in her writing document, think about using a phrase like Although we have no evidence of practical activism, her work demonstrates support for radical feminist and working-class issues.
